<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 194, 368, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 247, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 338, 228, 353]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 115, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>?</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 354, 118, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 354, 601, 370]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 370, 907, 400]]<|/det|>
For each question there are four possible answers \(\mathbf{A}\) , \(\mathbf{B}\) , \(\mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\) . Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 400, 579, 415]]<|/det|>
Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 416, 277, 431]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 431, 868, 462]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 462, 330, 476]]<|/det|>
Do not use correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 477, 364, 492]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 493, 329, 507]]<|/det|>
You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 508, 672, 524]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 550, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 566, 570, 616]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 40. Each correct answer will score one mark. Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 796, 89]]<|/det|> Which measuring instrument is used to measure the diameter of a thin metal wire? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 138, 117]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 100, 240, 117]]<|/det|> 30 cm rule <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 125, 133, 144]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 125, 284, 144]]<|/det|> measuring tape <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 133, 170]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 152, 240, 170]]<|/det|> metre rule <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 178, 133, 196]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 178, 358, 196]]<|/det|> micrometre screw gauge <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 222, 96, 241]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 297, 241]]<|/det|> A car starts from rest. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 253, 636, 272]]<|/det|> The table shows the readings from its speedometer every 10 s. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 280, 764, 351]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 288, 215, 310]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 325, 240, 346]]<|/det|>

<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 355, 235, 373]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 383, 133, 401]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 383, 260, 401]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 285, 532, 303]]<|/det|>
A student makes two statements about the waves.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 316, 207, 333]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 316, 920, 349]]<|/det|>
When the waves reflect from the barrier the direction changes but the wavelength remains the same.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 355, 205, 374]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|> An observer stands at the finish line of a 100 m race. He wants to time the winner's run. He starts his stop-watch as soon as he sees the smoke from the starting gun instead of when he hears the bang. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 395, 149]]<|/det|> What is the reason for doing this? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 160, 134, 177]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 160, 457, 177]]<|/det|> Light travels much faster than sound. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 186, 131, 203]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 186, 611, 203]]<|/det|> There is a risk he might respond to an echo from a wall. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 212, 131, 230]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 212, 512, 230]]<|/det|> Humans react slower to sound than to light. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 238, 133, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 238, 562, 256]]<|/det|> Humans react more quickly to sound than to light. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 284, 106, 301]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 282, 630, 301]]<|/det|> Which statement is not a method for magnetising an iron bar? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 312, 133, 329]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 311, 584, 329]]<|/det|> Place the bar next to a magnet and hammer the bar. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 338, 133, 356]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 337, 920, 370]]<|/det|> Place the bar inside a solenoid. Switch on an alternating current (a.c.) in the coil and gradually reduce the current. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 378, 131, 395]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 378, 920, 410]]<|/det|> Place the bar inside a solenoid. Switch on a direct current (d.c.) in the coil and gradually reduce the current. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 419, 133, 437]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 419, 490, 437]]<|/det|> Stroke the bar repeatedly with a magnet. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 463, 106, 482]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 463, 908, 482]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a circuit containing a variable resistor connected to a variable power supply. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 491, 576, 612]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 628, 920, 660]]<|/det|> The table shows the currents for different values of the potential difference (p.d.) and the resistance. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 672, 683, 777]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 616, 89]]<|/det|> Which statement about electromagnetic induction is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 134, 117]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 100, 920, 133]]<|/det|> A conductor moving parallel to magnetic field lines induces an electromotive force (e.m.f.) in the conductor. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 141, 134, 159]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 141, 920, 174]]<|/det|> The direction of the induced electromotive force (e.m.f.) opposes the change which produces it. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 131, 201]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 828, 200]]<|/det|> The induced current is in a direction parallel to the direction of motion producing it. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 209, 133, 227]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 207, 920, 240]]<|/det|> The induced electromotive force (e.m.f.) decreases when the speed of the conductor moving across the field lines increases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 268, 106, 286]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 268, 858, 285]]<|/det|> A very important experiment increased scientists' understanding of the structure of matter. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 298, 756, 315]]<|/det|> In the experiment, particles scattered as they passed through a thin metal foil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 329, 752, 345]]<|/det|> Which particles were used, and to which conclusion did the experiment lead? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 357, 658, 485]]<|/det|>
particlesconclusion
Aalpha-particlesmatter is made up of atoms
Balpha-particlesatoms have a very small nucleus
Cbeta-particlesmatter is made up of atoms
Dbeta-particlesatoms have a very small nucleus
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 513, 106, 531]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 513, 809, 530]]<|/det|> Polonium, Po, has a proton number equal to 84 and a nucleon number equal to 218. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 545, 606, 561]]<|/det|> Polonium changes into astatine, At, by emitting a \(\beta\)-particle. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 574, 440, 592]]<|/det|> Which equation represents this decay? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 606, 134, 626]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 606, 406, 626]]<|/det|> \(^{84}\mathrm{Po} \rightarrow ^{85}\mathrm{At} + \mathrm{}^{-\mathrm{1}}\beta\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 640, 134, 660]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 640, 406, 660]]<|/det|> \(^{84}\mathrm{Po} + \mathrm{}^{-\mathrm{1}}\beta \rightarrow ^{85}\mathrm{At}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 675, 134, 696]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 675, 406, 696]]<|/det|> \(^{218}\mathrm{Po} \rightarrow ^{218}\mathrm{At} + \mathrm{}^{-\mathrm{1}}\beta\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 710, 134, 730]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 710, 406, 732]]<|/det|> \(^{218}\mathrm{Po} + \mathrm{}^{-\mathrm{1}}\beta \rightarrow ^{218}\mathrm{At}\)
